description.narrative:
MRG Between July and December 2021, 29 victims of discrimination received legal assistance (21 cases are based on racial discrimination, 2 are based on SOGIESC, 2 are based on religion, 2 are related to GBV and 1 on disabilities).
In October 2021, MRG organised in Sousse the fourth and last training for lawyers on non-discrimination based on SOGIESC. 19 lawyers from Kef, Sousse, and Sfax attended this session including 11 women. Thus, 55 lawyers are now trained on the SOGIESC.
In December, MRG organised the first session of the lawyers’ training on non discrimination based on disabilities and Freedom of Religion or Belief (FoRB). 13 lawyers (including 9 women) from Tunis, Ariana, Ben Arous, Kef and Nabeul attended the session.
Following the journalists’ training that took place between February and March 2021, we organised a competition and 4 projects were selected to be supported by MRG. The first one, named "The Amazigh language: between the risk of extinction and the hope of victory" was released on the occasion of the international day for Indigenous peoples, 9th August. The video was seen 580 times on YouTube. MRG English webpage of the video received 729 visits and 454 visits for the French version. It was also shared in our weekly newsletters with 4686 remittee. 1141 opened the link in their emails. https://minorityrights.org/2021/08/10/amazigh-documentary-en/.
On the 1st December, World AIDS Day, MRG launched the second documentary winner of the competition: HIV in the time of the pandemic – a bitter reality. The video received 282 views on Youtube. MRG webpage received 295 visits for the English version and 79 for the French one. It was also shared in our weekly newsletters with 4130 remittee. 891 opened the email. https://minorityrights.org/2021/12/01/tunisia-hiv-en/
The 3rd short film, tackling issues of Sub-Saharan migrant women in Tunisia is still being edited. The 4th about a black Tunisian actress did not receive follow-up from the filmmaker despite several reminders from our team.
On the 18th of November, MRG released a Baseline study on the situation of minorities and discriminated groups in Tunisia. This baseline study aims to make an assessment of the progress and achievements in several areas, as well as the challenges that remain for a non-discriminatory Tunisia. The study also intends to shed light on the groups that continue to suffer from multiple forms of discrimination and to suggest recommendations. https://minorityrights.org/2021/11/26/tunisia-discrimination-en/
On the 1st of December, MRG released another report, Impact of Covid-19 on the rights of minorities and ‘minoritized’ populations: consultation with civil society. This study focuses on the impact of the pandemic on minorities and ‘minoritized’ populations in Tunisia. Most of these populations were in a situation of prior vulnerability which was worsened by the various measures taken by the Tunisian state to counter the spread of the epidemic. https://minorityrights.org/publications/tunisia-covid-19/
On the 1st of December, MRG organised a webinar in French with interpreting to Arabic and to English on "The situation of minorities and other ‘minoritized’ groups in Tunisia: between discrimination and recognition" in order to present the 2 studies (baseline study on the situation of minorities and discriminated groups in Tunisia and The impact of Covid-19 on the rights of minorities and ‘minoritized’ populations: consultation with civil society). Silvia Quattrini, North Africa Manager at MRG, moderated the webinar with the participation of the 2 authors of these reports and the presidents of civil society partners, Mnemty and ATP+. 50 person attended the webinar live and interacted with panellists. 347 entered the event page later and watched the webinar. 52 commented the webinar on social media and shared it. Up to today, 617 persons were reached. https://minorityrights.org/2021/11/26/tunisia-discrimination-en/
On the occasion of the Human Rights Day (10 December 2021), MRG organised a face-to-face event to present the reports and the short documentary films. Printed reports, goodies, along with flyers having our emergency numbers for consultation were distributed. The event started with an opening speech by Frerik Kampman, First Secretary of political affairs and human rights within the Dutch Embassy to Tunisia. The authors of the reports presented their work and answered questions. Then, 4 films were screened and discussedin the presence of the main characters and the directors. 45 attended the event including journalists,diplomats, researches and civil society organisation representatives. As a result, two interviews with local radio stations were conducted to discuss about discrimination in Tunisia.
In November 2021, we sent on behalf of the Bahai community a communication to the United Nations Special Rapporteur on religious freedom about the creation of a Bahai cemetery in Tunisia. This communication covers a request submitted by the Bahai community since 2017 asking the Minister of Local Affairs and Environment and the municipality of La Marsa to create a specific cemetery for the Bahai people in Tunisia in order to ensure respect for their dignity and rights, as Tunisian citizens, to have a funeral that respects their religious beliefs.
O3DT : Documentation of discrimination cases 214 cases of discrimination were documented by the Observatory’s (O3DT) coordinators. The documentation is reported as follows: - North-East: 61 cases documented - North-West: 30 cases documented - Central-East: 50 cases documented - Central-West: 31 cases documented - South-East: 17 cases documented - South-West: 25 cases documented
The Data Analysis Report of cases of discrimination documented between July 2021 and June 2021 will be released in January 2022. A press conference is planned for 12 January 2022.
Trainings and events The Observatory organized5 workshops on individual freedoms and minority rights in light of the events following July 25 during which the president Kais Said froze the activities of parliament, dismissed the head of government and seized all powers. Two other workshops are planned for early January. The objectives of the workshops were:
1. To present a reading of the political situation in Tunisia and the analysis of its impact on the rights and freedoms including those of minorities and this, by civil society organizations working on the issues.
2. Reflection on a common intervention strategy in the future. This workshop aimed to mobilize NGOs in a common front to defend rights and freedoms in case of their violation. 49 NGOs were present and mobilized. The workshops were held in: Tunis, Tozer, Djerba, and Kairouan. The O3DT started its second round of trainings on matters relevant to intersectionality and capacity building on capacities that minorities and associations working on non-discrimination can benefit of.
The first training was about digital security, tips and advice to protect human rights defenders and their associations. The training was held in Hammamet, on 17 and 18 December2021 and was facilitated by Houyem Mchirgui, a Tunisian digital security consultant and advocacy expert. 16 associations were present.
Social media, Newsletters and productions Four videos produced by the O3DT were released on its social media. Three of them present a sample of associations having different mandates and defending human rights in different regions of the country and one is a fiction entitled “Et si c’était toi ? “.

6 Newsletters were published, both through email and on the Observatory’s website: https://o3dt.org/newsletters/
Partnerships and call for projects Between July 2021 and December 2021, the O3DT supported 3 artistic projects led by the following Tunisian organizations : Transtyx, Mawjoudin, Danseurs Citoyens Sud.
The O3DT also supported 12 mini-projects promoting the right to be different in the Tunisian territory.The beneficiary local associations are: Association AMORCE Association Cinéma pour tous-Gabès, Association Le moulin-Testour, IBSAR Association Jeunes Créatifs Nefta, Association MADA Djerba, Association MERSET, Association MUSAIQUE-Médenine, Collectif OUTCAST, Association SOUTCOM, Association Volontaires Bouaradi Association festival Chrarda.
Research The Observatory commissioned 8 papers in the frame of its multidimensional study on the right to difference and non-discrimination. The topics of the papers and their writers are: - Why do Muslims fear the "right to be different"? by Faouzi Bedoui - Migrants and HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) In Tunisia, Challenges and Opportunities By Amira Mdimagh - Perception of discrimination on the basis of disability of people living with this situation by Imed Tarchi - Notes on the question of minorities in the Punic era by Mohamed Taher - Religious freedoms in Tunisia through judicial applications after 2011 by Habib Amara - Equal before the law without discrimination! Discrimination in Tunisian law by Wahid Ferchichi - Blacks and Colonial Situation: Ambiguous Identities and Discriminations in Tunisian Law By Mohamed Jouili - "Amazighs of Tunisia" - A semiotic study in the pictorial media discourse of the Amazighs and about the Amazighs by Amine Ben Massaoud
The public launch of the papers if planned for early February 2022
Networking and new members Between July and December 2021, 12 meetings were held with 12 associations to discuss joining the O3DT. 10 associations signed the charter and became part of the network.
Legal watch Since November 2021, the O3DT started conducting a legal watch to monitor any aspect of infringement of the right to non-discrimination in all texts. Legal (decree, orders, and decisions) issued every month. 8 decrees have been documented in November as well as 4 presidential orders. 10 decrees have been documented in December.
